p.s: In his speech Boris Johnson tries to introduce the present world leaders into the topic of climate change and give them a reason to fight against it, he uses diverse rhetorical devices to strengthen his position.
He gives a short welcome to the audience from which he immediatly leads into a comparison.
He compares this summit of leaders with a James Bond movie and points out the similarityssimilarities in the seemingly very rough position in front of a doomsday device.
This comparison is making the current state of the world more graspable and also dramatizes it to put pressure on the audience (l. 16).
He keeps this attitude of pressuring the audience in the next paragraphs when he recalls to past meetings and how their promises were either ignored or partly fulfilled.

Johnson sums up, that all this infuriated people all around the world and that all the built up rage will lash out on the present world leader if Glasgow comes to no conclusion or is another example for blah, blah, blah (l. 10ff.).

He used this term to critizescriticise the failure of politicians around the globe regarding climate change because this expression of baby language says nothing different than that a baby could have done similar things.
After this devastingdevastating introduction he begins his advances on convincing the audience of the effectiveness that his plans will have.
Johnson therefore gives hope to the audience with the elipsisellipsis and we can (l. 16) as answer to the rhetorical questions he used to end his introduction.
His intention behind it is to build up faith in his speech in the audience and also that everybody has an optimistic mindset on solving the issue of climate change going into this summit of leaders.
To support this he shortly enumerates in which crucial sectors we can achieve a massive effect on the development of climate change (l. 16).
It gives the impression that Johnson is eager to not make any false promises again.
With the mindset of the audience being very positive about alredyalready having all answers Johnson now tries to give reasons to perform the tasks at hand.
The reason behind it for Boris Johnson is based on his morale.
He sees a huge cjul of action on his generation due to 200 hundred years of ignoring and catalyzing the issue (l. 10f.).
Johnson states that they only need to fund the necessary actions which makes solving climate change look easy and achieveableachievable (l. 19ff).
But Johnson knows that this is only wishful thinking as all present world leaders do.
The problem is that the governments cannot afford it so Johnson proposes that all present should do their best to cooperate with the market and the multilateral development banks behind it (l. 22).
The incetivizeincentivize this behaviour he gives the example of hw the UK quit their reliance on coal by working with the private sector to builtbuild up windparks (l. 27).
He compares the results with the UK becoming the Saudi-Arabia of wind which implies that other countries can have a huge global impact by adapting the UK's strategy (l. 35).

After that he brings the subject of guilt back up and warns that if they do not achiveachieve something big in Glasgow they will be jufged for it by the youth and the future generations whomswhose lives got ravaged by the then unstoppable climate change.
Furthermore all this bitterness and hatred that will come in that case will be well-deserved (l. 30ff.).

Johnson demands that COP26 will not be the end of the story of climate change because this the last oportunityopportunity to turn the tide and it would put all in an unmeasurable debt if there are no actions.
In conclusion Boris Johnson gave a brief introduction on the issue of climate change and formulates his reason to try solving it.
His speech focused on just a few aspects to not overwhelm anyone in the beginning of the summit.
